item.title: Late Adulthood
item.description: Physical Development Brain shrinks; 5-10% loss in mass Brain volume decreases (up to 15%) Immune System Decline Low level of protein linked to decrease in T cells

item.title: Middle Adulthood
item.description: Change in physical appearance skin begins to wrinkle and sag because of a loss of fat and collagen in underlying tissues hair thins and greys pigmentation Height and weight

item.title: Perinatal Period
item.description: During or around birth

item.title: Sternberg's Triangular Theory of Love
item.description: Sternberg’s Triangular Theory of Love Intimacy Passion Commitment Non-love Liking/friendship ✔ Infatuated love ✔ Empty love ✔ Romantic love ✔ ✔ Companionate love ✔ ✔ Fatuous love ✔ ✔ Consummate love ✔ ✔ ✔

item.title: Developmental Research
item.description: Types of developmental research designs Cross-sectional design A cross-sectional study compares the behaviors of different age groups at a single time point.

item.title: Normative vs Idiographic
item.description: In Developmental Psychology, patterns of change can be - Normative Idiographic focuses on what we share in common focuses on individual differences “normal” or typical changes different for everyone milestones for babies, for example individual variations outside of the range of normative dev and why

item.title: Self Concept Scale
item.description: Introduction What is self concept? Self concept = collection of beliefs, self-perceptions, and cognitive schema about onself self concept is a framework that influences our motives, emotional states, abilities, etc

item.title: Aaron T Beck
item.description: ![[images/Aaron T Beck.jpg|100]] Aaron T Beck (July 18, 1921 – November 1, 2021) - influential psychiatrist who is regarded as the father of cognitive therapy and cognitive behavioural therapy.

item.title: Beck's Depression Inventory
item.description: made by [[Aaron T Beck]] published in 1961 Introduction 21-item, self-report rating inventory measures characteristic attitudes and symptoms of depression

item.title: FIRO B
item.description: Intro William Schultz 1950s 54 item questionnaire B = Behaviour three dimensions - inclusion, control, affection Inclusion assesses the degree to which a person associates with others.

item.title: Midlife Crisis
item.description: occurs usually around 40 - 60 Identity, role, self-doubt regarding : professional life achievements family psychological aspects > physical aspects in terms of effect

item.title: Stages of Grief
item.description: (⚠️ not enough empirical evidence) 5 stages of grief aka Kubler-Ross model flowchart LR A--B--C--D--E A(Denial) B(Anger) C(Bargaining) D(Depression) E(Acceptance)

item.title: Theories of Aging
item.description: [[Midlife Crisis| <- midlife crisis]] Theories of [[Senescence|Aging]] Genetic Preprogramming theory of aging [[Telomere]] length reduces every time a cell divides

item.title: Chess and Thomas' Temperament in infants
item.description: Temperament given by Alexandra Chess and Stetlla Thomas Three basic types of temperament - Easy Child generally positive mood

item.title: Kagan's Behavioural Inhibition
item.description: Classifying [[Temperament]] in infants based on differences between shy, subdued, timid child and a sociable, extraverted bold child Inhibited Children -

item.title: Temperament
item.description: An affective state More long standing than mood read also - [[mood]] [[emotions]] [[feelings]]

item.title: Assessing of newborns
item.description: APGAR Scale done at one and five minutes after A - Appearance P - Pulse G - Reflexes A - Activity

item.title: Birth Complications
item.description: Low birth weight - below 5.5 pounds - very low weight - extremely low weight - below 2.5 preterm infants small for date (aka small for gestational age)

item.title: Theories of Human Development
item.description: flowchart LR A(Theories of Human Development) subgraph psychoanalytic B(Psychosocial Theory by Erik Erikson) C(Psychosexual by Freud) end subgraph cognitive E(Piaget's Cognitive Dev) F(Vygotsky's Social Cognitive) G(Information Processing Theory) end subgraph etho S(Lorenz's Ethological) V(Bowlby's Attachment) R(Ainsworth's Attachment) end A---etho A---Q(Urie's Ecological) A---psychoanalytic A---cognitive see also: [[Introduction to Life Span Development#Perspectives / Key issues in Lifespan Development|Key issues in Lifespan Development]]

item.description: Bobo Doll experiment Observational Learning Bandura’s learning model triangle

item.description: definition strong emotional bond between two people Factors affecting attachment - During child’s development [[Freud]] - said only oral is important

item.title: Couvade Syndrome
item.description: etymology - the word couvade comes from the Breton word couver, which means to brood, hatch, or incubate Couvade syndrome is also called sympathetic pregnancy.

item.title: Emerging Adulthood
item.description: Emerging adulthood transition from adolescence to adulthood 18 - 25 characterized by experimentation and exploration Features Identity exploration, especially in love and work

item.title: Important Questions - Psychology
item.description: Define neonate and outline the patterns of development What are the three basic [[Temperament]]al styles Discuss the importance of friendship and peer relationships during adolescence Define language and biological influence on [[Language Development]] DIscuss types of reflexes in infants Stages of language development Describe the physical changes that occur during puberty Marcias Identity Statuses Explain components of language 9M

item.title: Important Questions - Psychology Mod 1
item.description: 5M Discuss the characteristics of development Identify any four issues in lifespan development Outline normative and ideographic patterns of development Identify any 4 ethical considerations in developmental research.

item.title: Life Span Development introduction
item.description: Life Span Development development from conception to death lifelong progressive orderly what is development? Development is the pattern of progressive, orderly

item.title: Marcia's Identity Statuses
item.description: Identity Diffusion Identity Foreclosure Identity Moratorium Identity Achievement based on [[Erik Erikson’s Psychosocial Stages]]

item.title: Moral Development Theory
item.description: by Lawrence Kohlberg [[Heinz Dilemma]] social and cultural norms LEARNT 3 levels - Preconventional (5-9) Stage 1. Obedience and Punishment

item.title: Parenting Styles
item.description: 2 dimensions - Parental Warmth = affection towards children Parental Control = promoting rules 4 styles - authoritative high warmth, high control

item.title: Pubery and Maturation
item.description: growth spurt, sexual maturation, adolescent sexuality, friendship and peer relations Role of friendships in development influence behaviour peer pressure

item.title: Rothbart and Bates' Temperament
item.description: Extraversion / surgency - includes positive anticipation impulsivity, activity level, and sensation seeking ([[Kagan’s Behavioural Inhibition]] - uninhibited children are part of this)

item.title: Scaffolding
item.description: Changing level of support over the course of a teaching session

item.title: Self Concept Development
item.description: Self Concept Definition Attributes, characteristics, what makes us us. physically, emotionally, socially, spiritually overall idea we have about who we are

item.title: Zeigarnik Effect
item.description: “An individual remembers the task until it is done” postulates that people remember unfinished or interrupted tasks better than completed tasks

item.title: Zone of Proximal Development
item.description: Space between what a learner can do without assistance and what a learner can do with adult guidance or in collaboration with more capable peers !
